Article.Title: Wildfire in Hyde County continues to burn heading into the July ...
Preview: A wildfire in Hyde County is slowly burning through thousands of acres of peat soil.

Article.Title: Winds bring down trees inside the Raleigh beltline
Preview: The Triangle had several reports of downed trees and rainy conditions as Hurricane Ian moves toward North Carolina. WRAL reporter Liz McLaughlin reported on a downed tree along East Whitaker Mill Road near Center Road in Raleigh.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Duke team gets global attention for rainforest drone project
Preview: At a class starting this week at Duke, students are working on a drone project with money on the line. The Blue Devil Rainforest Divers have reached the semifinals in an XPrize contest, a global competition with a ten million dollar purse.

Preview: When the moon is new or full and closest to Earth, the coast experiences "king tides."

Article.Title: Final public hearings set for Tuesday on carbon plan development
Preview: The NC Utilities Commission will hear public feedback at two hearings Tuesday for the carbon plan it must develop by the end of the year to reduce carbon emissions from energy plants in the state. There has been backlash from climate activists about Duke Energy's proposal, which some say relies to heavily on natural gas.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Supreme Court EPA ruling could shift focus to Cooper's climate plan
Preview: The U.S. Supreme Court's decision Thursday to limit federal agencies' ability to regulate greenhouse gas puts pressure on state and local authorities to enact their own regulations to combat carbon emissions, environmental law experts say.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Preview: Overfishing has caused a decline in the flounder population, prompting state regulators to impose limits on recreational fishing.

Preview: Concerned citizens in Durham County are pushing back against development that they say is tainting their waterways.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: 'It's insane we're forced to live this way'; North Carolina residents ...
Preview: Chemours, a spin-off of DuPont, is expanding production after letting toxic "forever chemicals" seep into the air, water, and soil. Thousands of North Carolina residents do not have clean drinking water at their homes because of the contamination.

Preview: Whether its a vacation rental or a dream home, beach properties are increasingly threatened by climate change.

Preview: Concerned citizens in Durham County are pushing back against development that they say is tainting their waterways.

Preview: Years after chemicals made by Chemours polluted drinking water for hundreds of thousands in North Carolina, many residents are still fighting to get access to clean water.

Preview: Durham County residents have noticed alarming changes to waterways after rapid development in the area, expressing concern about construction runoff contaminating drinking water. This, ahead of a Durham City-County meeting Tuesday with another development on the table that would span a massive 280 acres.

Preview: A small, invasive insect that was recently identified in North Carolina could be eating away at your next happy hour. The spotted lanternfly can damage dozens of crops, including wine grapes and hops used to brew beer.

Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: PFAS: 'Forever chemicals' part of widespread environmental crisis
Preview: Toxic so-called "forever chemicals" are found in everything from food packaging to rain gear to waterproof makeup... and in the blood of almost every American. In addition to consumer products, pollution from chemical companies such as Chemours has tainted North Carolina drinking water with PFAS. The chemicals are now circulating through our ecosystem from the rainwater to the food supply and they can remain in the environment for centuries.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: NC State researchers take aim at textile waste
Preview: NC State researchers have developed a way to separate cotton and polyester blend textiles using enzymes. The method could make it easier to recycle textiles, a waste stream that contributes an estimated 50 million tons to landfills across the globe each year.

Article.Title: How will offshore wind development impact North Carolina's coast?
Preview: There's a hot debate about the potential impacts of offshore wind development in the state. Many coastal residents came to an open house in Brunswick County Tuesday to voice their concerns after presentations from industry experts, academics, and government officials about the potential benefits and challenges of offshore wind.

Article.Title: How domestic and local efforts measure up to landmark UN climate ...
Preview: The latest United Nations report finds the world is on the brink of catastrophic warming, but there's still a chance to change course if the planet's biggest polluters can take swift action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Could the end of free returns help the environment?
Preview: Returns have been growing year over year, creating millions of pounds of waste and needless emissions from shipping. Major retailers are starting to charge for returns, which could have a positive impact on the environment.

Article.Title: Rise in taxes, gas price a double-whammy for your next fillup
Preview: On Jan. 2, AAA showed the average price of a tank of gas was back above $3 in Raleigh and across the state, about 10 cents higher than the week before. Meanwhile, the state is also tacking on an additional 2 cents per gallon, pushing that tax from 38.5 cents to 40.5 per gallon.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Lighting upgrades in NC schools saves hundreds of thousands ...
Preview: Sixty-nine schools across the state received replacement high-efficiency lights thanks to funding from the DEQ and NC Greenpower. The upgrades will save an estimated $250,000 each year.

Article.Title: "This is heartbreaking": Study finds dangerous chemicals in ...
Preview: Exposure to 'forever chemicals' from eating just one serving of freshwater fish is equivalent to drinking contaminated water for an entire month, according to an analysis of data from the Environmental Protection Agency.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Researchers find genes that help Christmas trees resist climate ...
Preview: Climate change is threatening Christmas tree crops, according to North Carolina State University researchers, who are working to make trees more resilient through genetics.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Duke Energy promotes program to encourage customers to pay ...
Preview: Duke Energy is encouraging customers to sign up for a program called "Renewable Advantage." It's pitched as "an easy way to support renewable energy and help reduce your environmental impact."
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Don't drink and drive this New Year's Eve
Preview: There are 71% more crashes involving alcohol and drugs in the 12-hour period straddling New Year's Eve than the average weekend night, according to SafeAuto.com.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: 95% of plastic waste isn't recycled
Preview: Only about 5% of plastic waste is recycled, meaning most of the plastic we use ends up in our landfills and oceans.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Nearly 200 countries gather for climate summit
Preview: After intense talks and growing pressure, U.S. climate envoy John Kerry and other leaders agreed to discuss the controversial topic of "loss and damage," reparations for poor countries on the front lines of climate change.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: The end of free returns could be good for the environment
Preview: Returns have been growing year over year, creating millions of pounds of waste and needless emissions from shipping. Major retailers are starting to charge for returns, which could have a positive impact on the environment.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Water shutoffs report: Pollution driving up water costs
Preview: More than 2 million Americans are living without access to clean water. A new report from the U.S. Water Alliance analyzed water shutoffs in eight cities and found that shutoffs are four times longer in majority-black communities.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: North Carolina, other states aiming to stop plastic pollution at the ...
Preview: As landfills across America reach capacity, a growing number of states are passing extended producer responsibility laws to curb waste at the source. Meanwhile, Orange County aims to reach zero waste by 2045.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: 'Eco-anxiety' has doubled in past 5 years, study finds
Preview: A recent study shows the number of people with "eco-anxiety" has doubled in the past five years.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Vote expected on whether to build police station on site with coal ash
Preview: Officials are meeting to discuss controversy surrounding a development site in Chapel Hill that sits on top of toxic coal ash.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: NC gas prices jump 11 cents in two weeks
Preview: On Jan. 2, AAA showed the average price of a tank of gas was back above $3 in Raleigh and across the state, about 10 cents higher than the week before. Meanwhile, the state is also tacking on an additional 2 cents per gallon, pushing that tax from 38.5 cents to 40.5 per gallon.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: NC schools getting green upgrades that will save $250000 per year
Preview: According to estimates from NC Greenpower, the non-profit that coordinated the light installation project, schools across the state will collectively save more than $250,000 each year.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Will widespread adoption of EVs crash the power grid?
Preview: It's possible, but Duke Energy says it's ready to adapt to a spike in demand by beefing up the grid and giving consumers incentives to charge vehicles during off-peak hours. Power concerns and lack of public infrastructure could be stifling widespread EV adoption.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Water shutoffs report: Black communities more likely to lack access ...
Preview: More than 2 million Americans are living without access to clean water. A new report from the U.S. Water Alliance analyzed water shutoffs in eight cities and found that shutoffs are four times longer in majority-black communities.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: NC State takes on textile waste
Preview: Various fabrics fill landfills across America. A researcher and a master's student at NC State are looking to change how much fabric is discarded.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: NC Water and Equity Summit focuses on serving underserved ...
Preview: North Carolina has earmarked more than 3 billion dollars to upgrade water infrastructure in the state, but Shadi Eskaf, director of the DEQ Division of Water Infrastructure, says there are far more applications than grants available.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin

Article.Title: Pilot, meteorologist killed in WBTV News helicopter crash in Charlotte
Preview: WBTV reported Tuesday afternoon that meteorologist Jason Myers and pilot Chip Tayag died in the crash along I-77 near Tyvola Road.
Key.Author: Liz McLaughlin
